moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3
comment: The well-known "struggle for the tempo." After 8. Bd3 dc4, Black gains a tempo, and hence white delays the development of his Bishop on f1.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3
comment: the struggle for the tempo continues.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4
comment: Black could have continued the struggle with 10...Re8 when 11 Qc2 is best.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7
comment: (12... c5 is less good because of 13. d5)

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O
comment: (13. b4 allows counterplay with 13... a5)

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4
comment: This releases the tension in the centre. A dubious idea in this position. This gives Black a queenside majority, which in the event of an ending might decide the game in his favour. But white gets a free hand in the centre which will prove dangerous in the middlegame.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5
comment: Probably the decisive mistake, since white's attack becomes more powerful than ever. This move allows white to put a pawn on e5, a very important pre-requisite for an attack, without much grave a weakness. Had white been forced to push e4-e5, his pawn at d4 becomes a terrible weakness.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5
comment: Now a central file is opened up which, white is better placed to benefit from.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7
comment: Forced. Bad would be (17... Nd5 18. Qc2) (17... Nd7 18. Qg4 Kh8 19. Qh5 when Qf7 and Bh6 are both threatened.)

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5
comment: threatening to win a pawn by Bh7+ and Qf7. Also possible was (18. Qg4 Bg5 19.Rcd1 {And then Bg3 and f4.)

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6
comment: This sacrifice is based on positional considerations. White obtains only two pawns for the piece but Black's king is exposed and white enjoys a long term initiative.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6
comment: forced. Declining the piece with (20... g6 21. Qg4 Qxe5 22. e4!leaves white with a powerful attack.)

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4
comment: The correct way. Wrong would be (21. Qxh6 Rad8 when black is out of danger.)

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5
comment: If (21... Bg5 22. h4 Qxe5 23. hxg5 hxg5 24. Rg4 {the attack still continues.)

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5 22. exf6 Bxf6 23. Rg4+ Bg7 24. Qxh6
comment: this is the position Euwe had in his mind when he sacrificed the bishop. The evaluation of the position depends on the comparative mobility of the pieces. Black's Knight on e8 and Bishop on g7 can not move and he'll require some time to mobilize both his rooks.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5 22. exf6 Bxf6 23. Rg4+ Bg7 24. Qxh6 Rad8 25. Ne2
comment: beautiful! The knight is heading for h5.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5 22. exf6 Bxf6 23. Rg4+ Bg7 24. Qxh6 Rad8 25. Ne2 e5
comment: In order to drive the white queen with ...Rd6 or ...Re6

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5 22. exf6 Bxf6 23. Rg4+ Bg7 24. Qxh6 Rad8 25. Ne2 e5 26. Ng3 Re6

1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5 22. exf6 Bxf6 23. Rg4+ Bg7 24. Qxh6 Rad8 25. Ne2 e5 26. Ng3 Re6 27. Qh4
comment: Now black's position appears well secured. He has effectively mobilized his rooks and apparently fend off the attack. But Euwe has something up his sleeve.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5 22. exf6 Bxf6 23. Rg4+ Bg7 24. Qxh6 Rad8 25. Ne2 e5 26. Ng3 Re6 27. Qh4 Rd3
comment: A difficult situation.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5 22. exf6 Bxf6 23. Rg4+ Bg7 24. Qxh6 Rad8 25. Ne2 e5 26. Ng3 Re6 27. Qh4 Rd3 28. Nf5 Ng6 29. Qh5 Qf7 30. h4
comment: Decisive! Euwe must have seen this many moves earlier. When the attack with only pieces comes to a standstill, White manages to stimulate the attack with the help of the h-pawn. The threat being Qg5 and h5 winning a piece, which is very difficult to parry.

moves: 1. d4 d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5 Be7 5. e3 O-O 6. Nf3 Nbd7 7. Rc1 c6 8. a3 h6 9. Bf4 a6 10. h3 dxc4 11. Bxc4 b5 12. Ba2 Bb7 13. O-O c5 14. Ne5 c4 15. Bb1 Re8 16. Qe2 Nxe5 17. dxe5 Nh7 18. Qh5 Nf8 19. Rcd1 Qc7 20. Bxh6 gxh6 21. Rd4 f5 22. exf6 Bxf6 23. Rg4+ Bg7 24. Qxh6 Rad8 25. Ne2 e5 26. Ng3 Re6 27. Qh4 Rd3 28. Nf5 Ng6 29. Qh5 Qf7 30. h4 Bf8 31. Nh6+ Bxh6 32. Qxh6 Qh7 33. Qg5 Kf7 34. Bxd3 cxd3 35. Qf5+
comment:
Here Black resigned as Black's position is hopeless after 35... Ke7 36. h5 Nf8 37. Qxh7+ Nxh7 38. Rg7+ Or 35... Rf6 36. Qd7+ Kg8 37. Qe8+ Kg7 38. Qe7+ Rf7 39. Qxe5+ Kf8 40. Qd6+ Kg7 41. Qxd3 
Dr. Euwe justly received Brilliancy Prize for this game.
